author: jeffbi
body:
This is similar to #3414, but involves only the backslash portion.

The basis of the problem is premature normalization of paths. Path normalization happens quite early (and *very* frequently and in a great number of places in the PowerShell code) while processing a command. Usually this happens before the path reaches its provider, and often that normalization is a brute-force change one slash to another mechanism. Thus a path such as `1\2` on Unix is "normalized" to `1/2`, ensuring that the path will never be found.

Using `-LiteralPath` does not prevent the path normalization, so that is not a workaround.

Steps to reproduce
------------------
From bash:
```bash
$ touch 'a\b'
```
then from PowerShell:
```PowerShell
PS> Remove-Item a\b
```
or
```PowerShell
PS> Move-Item a\b a-b
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
The file `a\b` is deleted

Actual behavior
---------------
```
Remove-Item : Cannot find path 'a/b' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ Remove-Item a\b
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (a/b:String) 
    [Remove-Item], ItemNotFoundException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.RemoveItemCommand
```

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value                                                     
----                           -----                                                     
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0                                                   
CLRVersion                                                                               
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.18-38-g08e855556cff42274a5903799b826e78d0c...
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                                   
PSEdition                      Core                                                      
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                                       
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha                                               
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1                                                   
WSManStackVersion              3.0                                                       
```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
`-literalpath` should not normalize

In the `get-childitem` case, we'll need to be smarter in the filesystem provider because it tries to normalize all the time.  When it finds the file `a\b` it needs to know that this is literal.

comments.author: vors
comments.body:
Hit it again today, because of https://github.com/PowerShell/Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive/issues/11
The above issue makes the `\` very common char in the unzipped names on macOS.

I think both escaping and literal path are not good solutions, because they break all the normal ways that we work with files in powershell

```
PS /Users/vors/junk/baskslash> ls                                                                                    
untitled\folder
PS /Users/vors/junk/baskslash> Get-ChildItem . | Remove-Item                                                         
Remove-Item : Cannot find path '/Users/vors/junk/baskslash/untitled\folder' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:19
+ Get-ChildItem . | Remove-Item
+                   ~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (/Users/vors/jun...untitled\folder:String) [Remove-Item], ItemNotFoun 
   dException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.RemoveItemCommand
```

Like, that stuff should just work, no matter what.
As one mitigation for interactive only usage, a good tab-completion (that adds escaping) can help. It's the same as tab-completion that adds quotes to handle whitespaces in the names.

comments.author: vors
comments.body:
Also literal path doesn't work

```
Get-ChildItem . | % { Remove-Item -LiteralPath $_.Name }
```

But I would argue that it's not the right way to fix it.
We can error out if the command is ambiguous, but when it's not we should just silently execute that.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
This discussion came up again on #8587, and I want to note for later that we should really look at the pipelining scenario described by @vors above. 

Unfortunately, I think that the logic we applied to solving that issue (valid globbing characters in Linux filenames) is worse when we're talking about a "valid" (at least to Windows) path separator in a Linux filename. 

To me, the scenario we need to solve here is the one where folks used to paths on Windows will be contributing to or sharing scripts with folks used to paths on Linux. Furthermore, one of our primary goals right now is enabling more backwards compatibility with existing scripts and modules. 

With both of those in my mind, **I think it's fair to rule out ever requiring Windows users to conform to Linux and use forward slashes**. 

On a more positive note, I think that enabling escaping of backslashes (which we may have already done to some degree) is certainly a step in the right direction, even if it doesn't solve the pipelining issue. **Is there any reason someone sees *not* to do this?**

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
The FileSystemProvider is overly aggressive in normalizing the path, so even:

```powershell
set-content -literalpath "a\b.txt" -value "hello"
```

Creates a `b.txt` within a folder `a` (assuming this exists) rather than a file called `a\b.txt`.

I think if we have a literalpath with a backslash and not on Windows, it should be escaped and preserved.  The path normalization would take this into account and not blindly replace slashes.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
I'd start with design. We want magic features but every time fallback to platform specific implementation details.
What is the main goal? I believe it is having portable scripts.
At the same time, we need to give users the ability to perform low-level operations (such as described in description of the issue).
Currently, path portability is achieved by means of aggressive normalization. It has several side effects and they _cannot be eliminated_ completely without adding complexity to the language or/and rules.
I'd split file provider to two levels - high (portable) and low (platform specific). Then introduce [portable] path (PSSA will understand this!). Perhaps non-portable could be default in console or we could have a switch for the mode. Perhaps we could do agressive normalization while user types a path and force typing backstick to escape and stop the normalization. Perhaps we could have syntax sugar for [portablepath]/[non-portablepath] to enhance current Path/LiteralPath experience.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: I think the default behavior with `-Path` is fine for portability reasons.  I can see how `a\b.txt` would be problematic used with `-LiteralPath` as it would do different things on Windows vs Unix.  However, ``a`\b.txt`` where the backslash is escaped should be honored.

title: On Unix, PowerShell will not find files with backslashes in their names
